content:
import { Terminal, Network, Boxes, Zap, Shield, Globe2, Code2, Server, Lock } from 'lucide-react'
{/* Hero Section */}
DEKA CLI

Infrastructure as code. Batteries included.

Command-line tools to deploy, manage, and scale your runtime infrastructure. Works with any framework.

Single binary deployment
Mesh networking built-in
Zero-trust security
{/* Command Examples */}

Simple commands, powerful infrastructure

Deploy and manage your runtime with intuitive CLI commands. No complex configuration, just infrastructure that works.

{/* Deploy */}

Deploy a handler

# Deploy your handler
deka deploy handler.ts
# Deploy with environment
deka deploy handler.ts --env production
{/* Runtime Management */}

Manage runtime

# Start runtime
deka start
# Check status
deka status
{/* Mesh Networking */}

Join mesh network

# Connect to mesh
deka mesh join
# List peers
deka mesh peers
{/* Logs & Debug */}

Monitor & debug

# Stream logs
deka logs --follow
# Performance metrics
deka metrics
{/* Mesh Networking Section */}
MESH NETWORKING

Tailscale-compatible mesh networking

Built-in mesh networking that's compatible with Tailscale. Connect your runtime nodes securely across regions, clouds, or on-premise infrastructure.

  • Zero-trust security with WireGuard encryption
  • Automatic peer discovery and NAT traversal
  • Cross-region connectivity without complex VPN setup
  • Compatible with existing Tailscale networks

Mesh Network Architecture

Runtime Node A
us-east-1 • 100.64.1.2
Runtime Node B
eu-west-1 • 100.64.1.3
Runtime Node C
on-premise • 100.64.1.4
{/* Framework Agnostic Section */}

Works with any framework

Deka provides the infrastructure layer. Use React, Vue, Svelte, or any framework you prefer. We support them all by building the runtime they depend on.

Framework agnostic

Deploy Next.js, Remix, SvelteKit, or any framework. Deka provides the runtime infrastructure.

Infrastructure primitives

Built-in database, queues, cron, and secrets management. Framework handles UI, Deka handles infrastructure.

Deploy anywhere

Single binary deployment works on bare metal, VMs, containers, or edge locations.

{/* CTA Section */}

Coming Soon: Infrastructure that works with everything.

Deka CLI is in active development. Follow our progress and be the first to know when it's ready.

Early Prototype: CLI tools and mesh networking under active development. Public release coming soon.
html:

# deka whoami

Show the current user and role on this instance.

```bash
deka whoami
```

## Options

- `-s, --server <url>` - Deka API URL (default: http://localhost:8520)

## Example output

```text
$ deka whoami
@samifouad (admin)
```
html:
deka whoami

Show the current user and role on this instance.

Options

  • -s, --server <url> - Deka API URL (default: http://localhost:8520)

Example output

content:
# deka logs

Tail logs for a specific service.

```bash
deka logs [service]
```

## Options

- `-f, --follow` - Follow log output
- `-n, --tail <lines>` - Number of lines to show (default: 100)

Follow logs in real time:

```bash
deka logs -f deploy
```

## Example output

```text
$ deka logs -f deploy
[deploy] starting build 7f9b2c
[deploy] cloning repo deka-example
[deploy] build complete in 42s
```
html:
deka logs

Tail logs for a specific service.

Options

  • -f, --follow - Follow log output
  • -n, --tail <lines> - Number of lines to show (default: 100)

Follow logs in real time:

Example output

codeBlocks.code:
$ deka logs -f deploy
[deploy] starting build 7f9b2c
[deploy] cloning repo deka-example
[deploy] build complete in 42s

Stop Deka services or specific services by name.


To stop everything and remove volumes:

```bash
deka stop all --volumes
```

# deka update

Pull the latest images without restarting containers.

```bash
deka update
```

## Options

- `-a, --all` - Pull all images, not just outdated ones
- `-q, --quiet` - Suppress progress output

Check for updates first:

```bash
deka check
```

## Example output

```text
$ deka update
pulling ghcr.io/tananetwork/edge:1.12.0
pull complete
```
html:
deka update

Pull the latest images without restarting containers.

Options

  • -a, --all - Pull all images, not just outdated ones
  • -q, --quiet - Suppress progress output

Check for updates first:

Example output

codeBlocks.code:
$ deka update
pulling ghcr.io/tananetwork/edge:1.12.0
pull complete

# deka repo list

List repositories on the deka server.

```bash
deka repo list
```

Aliases: `deka repo ls`

## Options

- `-q, --jq <expression>` - Filter JSON output using a jq expression
- `--json [fields]` - Output JSON with the specified fields
- `-l, --language <lang>` - Filter by primary coding language
- `--topic <topics...>` - Filter by topic

## Example output

```text
$ deka repo list
core/runtime
core/identity
apps/deka-dashboard
```
html:
deka repo list

List repositories on the deka server.

Aliases: deka repo ls

Options

  • -q, --jq <expression> - Filter JSON output using a jq expression
  • --json [fields] - Output JSON with the specified fields
  • -l, --language <lang> - Filter by primary coding language
  • --topic <topics...> - Filter by topic

Example output

codeBlocks.code:
$ deka repo list
core/runtime
core/identity
apps/deka-dashboard

content:
# deka start

Start the full Deka hosting stack.

```bash
deka start
```

## Options

- `--genesis` - Initialize genesis block on first start
- `-d, --detach` - Run in background (default: true)
- `--infra` - Start only infrastructure services (postgres, redis) and expose ports for local dev

Infrastructure mode exposes:

- postgres: `postgres://tana:tana_dev_password@localhost:5432/tana`
- redis: `redis://localhost:6380`
- pgbouncer: `postgres://tana:tana_contract_password@localhost:6432/<db>`

## Example output

```text
$ deka start
✓ docker running
✓ postgres ready
✓ redis ready
✓ migrations complete
✓ edge ready
✓ t4 ready
✓ deka-git ready
✓ deploy ready
```
html:
deka start

Start the full Deka hosting stack.

Options

  • --genesis - Initialize genesis block on first start
  • -d, --detach - Run in background (default: true)
  • --infra - Start only infrastructure services (postgres, redis) and expose ports for local dev

Infrastructure mode exposes:

  • postgres: postgres://tana:tana_dev_password@localhost:5432/tana
  • redis: redis://localhost:6380
  • pgbouncer: postgres://tana:tana_contract_password@localhost:6432/<db>

Example output

codeBlocks.code:
$ deka start
✓ docker running
✓ postgres ready
✓ redis ready
✓ migrations complete
✓ edge ready
✓ t4 ready
✓ deka-git ready
✓ deploy ready

content:
# deka setup

Run the interactive setup before your first deployment. It writes configuration and prepares your registry auth.

```bash
deka setup
```

## What it configures

- Container registry access
- Runtime service defaults
- Deployment preferences and storage paths

Config is stored under `~/.config/deka/` so you can re-run setup safely when you need to rotate credentials.

If registry authentication fails, you can also run:

```bash
docker login ghcr.io
```
html:
deka setup

Run the interactive setup before your first deployment. It writes configuration and prepares your registry auth.

What it configures

  • Container registry access
  • Runtime service defaults
  • Deployment preferences and storage paths

Config is stored under ~/.config/deka/ so you can re-run setup safely when you need to rotate credentials.

If registry authentication fails, you can also run:

# deka c attach

Attach to a running container with an interactive shell.

```bash
deka c attach <container> [cmd]
```

If no command is provided, the default is `/bin/sh`.
html:
deka c attach

Attach to a running container with an interactive shell.

If no command is provided, the default is /bin/sh.

Execute a command in a running container.

```bash
deka c exec <container> [cmd...]
```

## Options

- `-i, --interactive` - Interactive mode (allocate TTY)

Example:

```bash
deka c exec edge ls -la
```

Execute a command in a running container.

```bash
deka status
```

```text
● [postgres] healthy :5432
● [redis] healthy :6379
● [edge] running :8506
● [t4] running :8507
● [deka-git] running :8508
● [deploy] running :8509
```

```text
● [redis] healthy :6379
● [edge] running :8506
● [t4] running :8507
● [deka-git] running :8508
● [deploy] running :8509
```

# deka monitor

Manage automatic update checks (runs every 5 minutes).

## Start monitoring

```bash
deka monitor start
```

## Options

- `--upgrade` - Use upgrade instead of update (restarts containers)

## Stop monitoring

```bash
deka monitor stop
```

## Status

```bash
deka monitor status
```
html:
deka monitor

Manage automatic update checks (runs every 5 minutes).

Start monitoring

Options

  • --upgrade - Use upgrade instead of update (restarts containers)

Stop monitoring

Status

# deka c ps

List containers managed by the deka-agent.

```bash
deka c ps
```

## Options

- `-a, --all` - Show all containers (including stopped)
- `--json` - Output JSON

## Example output

```text
$ deka c ps
NAME        IMAGE                          STATUS
edge        ghcr.io/tananetwork/edge:1.12  running
postgres    postgres:16                    running
```

deka c ps

List containers managed by the deka-agent.

Options

  • -a, --all - Show all containers (including stopped)
  • --json - Output JSON

codeBlocks.code:

NAME        IMAGE                          STATUS
edge        ghcr.io/tananetwork/edge:1.12  running

metadata.description: Upgrade services and clean up old images

content:
# deka upgrade

Stop, pull, restart outdated containers and cleanup old images.

```bash
deka upgrade
```

## Options

- `-q, --quiet` - Suppress progress output

## Example output

```text
$ deka upgrade
stopping edge
pulling ghcr.io/tananetwork/edge:1.12.0
starting edge
cleaned up old images
```
html:
deka upgrade

Stop, pull, restart outdated containers and cleanup old images.

Options

  • -q, --quiet - Suppress progress output

Example output

codeBlocks.code:
$ deka upgrade
stopping edge
pulling ghcr.io/tananetwork/edge:1.12.0
starting edge
cleaned up old images

- `-f, --force` - Force removal (kills if running)
- `-y, --yes` - Skip confirmation

content:
# deka run

Execute a JavaScript or TypeScript entrypoint with deka-runtime.

```bash
deka run <entry> [args...]
```

## Options

- `--deka` - Force deka-runtime even if the entry has a node/bun shebang
- `--runtime-bin <path>` - Path to the deka-runtime binary

Example:

```bash
deka run ./scripts/hello.ts
```

Force deka-runtime for a Node/Bun CLI:

```bash
deka run --deka vite
```
html:
deka run

Execute a JavaScript or TypeScript entrypoint with deka-runtime.

Options

  • --deka - Force deka-runtime even if the entry has a node/bun shebang
  • --runtime-bin <path> - Path to the deka-runtime binary

Example:

Force deka-runtime for a Node/Bun CLI:

content:
# deka c run

Create and start a container via deka-agent.

```bash
deka c run <name> <image>
```

## Options

- `-p, --port <mapping...>` - Port mappings (host:container)
- `-e, --env <var...>` - Environment variables (KEY=VALUE)
- `-d, --detach` - Run in background (default: true)

Example:

```bash
deka c run web nginx:latest -p 8080:80 -e NODE_ENV=production
```
html:
deka c run

Create and start a container via deka-agent.

Options

  • -p, --port <mapping...> - Port mappings (host:container)
  • -e, --env <var...> - Environment variables (KEY=VALUE)
  • -d, --detach - Run in background (default: true)

Example:

codeBlocks.code: deka c run web nginx:latest -p 8080:80 -e NODE_ENV=production
